title: Wood Chip Pad Winter Feeding Area as a New Livestock Manure Management System

tasks.task: Discussing the concept of feeding cattle on pastures during the dormant period and its effects on soil and water.
subtasks: Mention the preliminary data and mature technology behind wintering sites for cattle in wet and rainy regions.
Highlight the significant soil compaction, runoff, and sediment loss during the winter feeding period compared to other grazing periods.
Present the classic study by Owens et al. showing 60% sediment loss during the winter period and reduced runoff when cattle are removed.
Emphasize the impact of winter feeding areas on pasture production and conservation practices.

tasks.task: Explain the wood chip design for winter feeding pads and their benefits.
subtasks: Describe the engineered heavy use areas (outwintering pads) inspired by New Zealand and British methods.
Detail the construction process, including clay soil, drainage, aggregate stone, and wood chip base in clay subsoils.
Mention the use of local, non-valuable timber for wood chips, providing environmental benefits and cost-effective materials.
Provide examples of cattle performance on wood chip pads, comparing them to indoor systems and traditional earthen pads.

tasks.task: Present results and costs associated with wood chip winter feeding pads.
subtasks: Share the preliminary data on 12 storm events, comparing wood chip pads to concrete and earthen pads.
Highlight the wood chip pad's performance in managing nutrient cycling, reducing nitrogen and phosphorus runoff.
Discuss the lifecycle of the wooden chips (fist-sized chips lasting 5-7 years) and their management.
Address challenges in sourcing appropriate wood chip sizes and materials.

tasks.task: Summarize key points and future directions.
subtasks: Conclude with the necessity of moving cattle from pastures during the dormant period to prevent soil erosion and sediment loss.
Mention ongoing research and collaboration with University of Vermont and West Virginia University for feasible and effective wood chip designs.
Note the potential for wood chip pads as a sustainable solution while managing costs and environmental impact.
Acknowledge the need for further refinements in chip size and source to enhance pad performance and efficiency.
